misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Sorting one parallel array updates the other (parallel-array synchronization misconception)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the scores array will keep the names array aligned automatically, so the highest score after sorting (z[n-1]) still corresponds to the correct student name at y[n-1].
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects. `Arrays.sort(z)` reorders only the elements of `z`; it does not (and cannot) rearrange elements in a separate array `y`. For parallel arrays, you must swap elements in both arrays together during sorting, or sort indices/objects that bind name+score as one unit.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: prints a name that is not actually associated with the highest score (unless the original input order happens to match the sorted score order).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting one array in a parallel array structure will automatically reorder the corresponding elements in the other array, or that the index-based association between the two arrays is inherently managed by the Java execution environment during library-led sorting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to recognize that parallel arrays are independent memory structures with no built-in link. Arrays.sort() is a destructive operation that only affects the array passed as an argument; it does not apply the same permutation to other logically related arrays, leading to a loss of data integrity.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay aligned after sorting one array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the scores array will also (implicitly) reorder the names array in the same way, so that the last name y[n-1] will still correspond to the highest score after Arrays.sort(z).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, Arrays.sort(z) only rearranges the elements of the int[] z. It does not know about (or update) a separate String[] y. Parallel arrays require swapping/moving both arrays together using the same permutation (or sorting indices/objects), otherwise the association between name and score is lost.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: it prints the highest score correctly (z[n-1]) but may print the wrong student name (y[n-1] is just the last input name, not necessarily the top scorer).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting only the scores array while leaving the names array unmodified will correctly maintain the pairing between student names and scores. They assume that after sorting scores, accessing both arrays at index [n-1] will give the correct name and highest score.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: When using parallel arrays, both arrays share the same index structure to maintain correspondence between related data. Sorting only one array breaks this correspondence. The student did not recognize that sorting operations on parallel arrays must either: (1) sort both arrays using identical operations on paired elements, or (2) use a more sophisticated approach like tracking indices or creating wrapper objects. By sorting only the scores array, the index alignment is destroyed.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output - the program pairs the highest score with an incorrect student name. For the given sample input, it outputs 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of 'Top student: Bob (92)' because Charlie is the last name entered, not the student with the highest score.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that since the 'names' and 'scores' arrays are logically related, performing a sort operation on the 'scores' array will automatically rearrange the 'names' array to maintain the original data pairings.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, parallel arrays are independent memory structures with no inherent link. Sorting one array modifies its indices without affecting any other arrays. To maintain parallelism, the programmer must manually swap elements in both arrays using the same logic or use an object-oriented approach.
